div.head: Book I. The Dunciad. 43
div.p: Still her old Empire to restore she tries,

For, born a Goddess, Dulness never dies.
A note.
O thou! whatever title please thine ear,
Whether thou choose Cervantes’ serious air,
Or laugh and shake in Rabelais’ easy chair,
Or praise the court, or magnify mankind,
Or thy grieved country’s copper chains unbind;
25 From thy Boeotia though her power retires,
Mourn not, my Swift, at ought our realm acquires,
Here pleased behold her mighty wings out-spread
To hatch a new Saturnian age of lead.
Close to those walls where Folly holds her throne,
30 And laughs to think Monroe would take her down,
